## Search Results Summary

Your search query focused on "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" (Przygody Tomka Sawyera) in relation to PRL censorship, communism, and American literature. Here's what the search revealed:

### About "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" in Poland

The Adventures of Tom Sawyer (Przygody Tomka Sawyera) is a novel for young people by American writer Mark Twain from 1876, with the first Polish edition published in 1901. The Adventures of Tom Sawyer is the most famous novel for young people by American writer Mark Twain.

The novel has been continuously available in Polish translations throughout different periods, including during the PRL era. There was even a Soviet film adaptation "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn" from 1981, directed by Stanisław Goworuchin.

### Censorship in PRL (Communist Poland)

Censorship in the Polish People's Republic was a phenomenon of supervision by PRL authorities over information (press, scientific and cultural publications, performances) intended for distribution. Censorship in People's Poland lasted from 1944 to 1990 and functioned in the form of the Main Office for Control of Press, Publications and Performances (GUKPPiW) established by decree in 1946.

Censorship in PRL was all-encompassing, covering everything. It was meant to help create a certain positive image of the state in political, civilizational, and economic terms, popularize it and prevent its undermining.

### Targets of Communist Censorship

The tasks of censorship, defined during censor briefings in 1948, were: "Counteracting attacks by the clergy, paralyzing Anglo-Saxon infiltration and propaganda, counteracting anti-Soviet propaganda, fighting for a new psyche of the citizen of new Poland".

Every manifestation of criticism of the functioning system and the propagation of Western political ideas was censored. About US or Israeli politics, one could only write critically, also for example in the sphere of technological achievements.

### Extent of Censorship

Censorship activities covered even children's books, scientific works, announcements, leaflets, and obituaries. Censorship in PRL consisted of preventive control (i.e., preceding the publication of text or presentation of work) of everything that had the character of public information. Not only all printed materials were subject to it, but also radio and television broadcasts, film materials, slides, artistic and entertainment events, information posters.

### American Literature and Censorship

While the search results don't provide specific examples of how "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" was censored in communist Poland, they do show that there was systematic "paralyzing of Anglo-Saxon infiltration and propaganda" as one of the main censorship objectives.

Interestingly, one search result references a scholarly article about "political correctness in the translation of children's literature" that focuses on how Polish translators of Mark Twain's "Adventures of Tom Sawyer" dealt with descriptions of the Black minority, examining the notion of political correctness and its role in works written for young audiences.

The search results suggest that while Mark Twain's works were available in Poland during the PRL period, the broader context of systematic censorship of Western, particularly American, cultural influences was pervasive throughout the communist era.
